elements.content: A three-dimensional polymer, {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)(H2O)} n (1) (DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), has been synthesized using solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O with a linear ligand bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl] benzoic acid (pyebH). It has a 7-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) diamondoid structure (dia) having 66 uninodal net with triangular channels that are filled with DMF and water as guest molecules. When a crystal of 1 is kept in acetone at RT for 12 h, all guest molecules are replaced by acetone molecules to afford the daughter product, {[Zn(pyeb)2](acetone)} n (2) in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation. When this crystal 2 is kept in acetonitrile for 12 h, a new product, {[Zn(pyeb)2](MeCN)} n (3) is formed again without losing crystallinity. Interestingly, when either 2 or 3 is kept in dry DMF for 12 h, a new compound, {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)} n (4) is formed. Compound 1 can be regenerated by keeping 2, 3, or 4 in aqueous DMF for 12 h at RT. All these transformations are achieved in SC-SC fashion. The compounds are characterized by X-ray crystallography, thermogravimetery, and infrared spectroscopy.

It has a 7-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) diamondoid structure (dia) having 66 uninodal net with triangular channels that are filled with DMF and water as guest molecules. When a crystal of 1 is kept in acetone at RT for 12 h, all guest molecules are replaced by acetone molecules to afford the daughter product, {[Zn(pyeb)2](acetone)} n  (2) in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation. When this crystal 2 is kept in acetonitrile for 12 h, a new product, {[Zn(pyeb)2](MeCN)} n  (3) is formed again without losing crystallinity. Interestingly, when either 2 or 3 is kept in dry DMF for 12 h, a new compound, {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)} n  (4) is formed. Compound 1 can be regenerated by keeping 2, 3, or 4 in aqueous DMF for 12 h at RT. All these transformations are achieved in SC-SC fashion. The compounds are characterized by X-ray crystallography, thermogravimetery, and infrared spectroscopy.

elements.content: A three-dimensional coordination polymer (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. It has a 7-fold interpenetrating diamondoid structure (dia) having 66 uninodal net with triangular channels filled with DMF and water as guest molecules. The lattice solvent molecules can be replaced with different solvent molecules such as acetone and acetonitrile in a reversible single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) manner.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional coordination polymer (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. It has a 7-fold interpenetrating diamondoid structure (dia) having 66 uninodal net with triangular channels filled with DMF and water as guest molecules. The lattice solvent molecules can be replaced with different solvent molecules such as acetone and acetonitrile in a reversible single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) manner.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of coordination polymers are of considerable current interest because of their potential applications. The organic linkers that combine with metal ions to generate these structures can be designed to vary in rigidity and in spatial disposition of the binding atoms to have frameworks with desirable architecture for carrying out specific tasks related to host−guest chemistry. Guest molecules occupy void spaces in an open framework where they are involved in several types of noncovalent interactions such as H-bonding, π···π stacking, and so forth with the framework as well as among themselves. These guest molecules can sometimes be replaced by another set of molecules. If the guest exchange takes place without losing crystallinity of the host, the exact nature of the noncovalent forces between the host and various guests can be studied by crystallography. This in turn, helps tune the void space in terms of size and shape for desired selectivity of guest binding. Such studies have the ultimate goal(s) of activating small molecules inside the void spaces that can lead to chemical transformations. Such single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformations are still a challenge since crystals can hardly retain their crystallinity after solid-state rearrangement of the molecules. However, a few metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are reported where the process of guest desorption−resorption, guest-exchange, and photochemical cycloaddition reactions have been observed in SC-SC fashion.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and synthesis of coordination polymers are of considerable current interest because of their potential applications. The organic linkers that combine with metal ions to generate these structures can be designed to vary in rigidity and in spatial disposition of the binding atoms to have frameworks with desirable architecture for carrying out specific tasks related to host-guest chemistry. Guest molecules occupy void spaces in an open framework where they are involved in several types of noncovalent interactions such as H-bonding, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking, and so forth with the framework as well as among themselves. These guest molecules can sometimes be replaced by another set of molecules. If the guest exchange takes place without losing crystallinity of the host, the exact nature of the noncovalent forces between the host and various guests can be studied by crystallography. This in turn, helps tune the void space in terms of size and shape for desired selectivity of guest binding. Such studies have the ultimate goal(s) of activating small molecules inside the void spaces that can lead to chemical transformations. Such single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformations are still a challenge since crystals can hardly retain their crystallinity after solid-state rearrangement of the molecules. However, a few metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are reported where the process of guest desorption-resorption, guest-exchange, and photochemical cycloaddition reactions have been observed in SC-SC fashion.

elements.content: Among various coordination polymers, interpenetration is frequently observed especially in diamondoid and polyrotaxane networks. Linear organic linkers and metal ions with a strong tendency for tetrahedral or octahedral coordination are known to form diamondoid networks with various degrees of interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: Among various coordination polymers, interpenetration is frequently observed especially in diamondoid and polyrotaxane networks. Linear organic linkers and metal ions with a strong tendency for tetrahedral or octahedral coordination are known to form diamondoid networks with various degrees of interpenetration.

elements.content: Herein, we describe a three-dimensional diamondoid coordination polymer constructed with Zn(II) ion and a linear rigid ligand, bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl] benzoic acid (pyebH) (Scheme ). The structural analysis reveals extensive interpenetration. However, the compound exhibits guest exchange properties in a reversible SC-SC fashion.

The structural analysis reveals extensive interpenetration. However, the compound exhibits guest exchange properties in a reversible SC-SC fashion.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The 4-picoline (99%), 4-formylbenzoic acid (97%) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98%) were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India and purified prior to use.

elements.content: Infrared (IR) spectra (KBr disk, 400−4000 cm−1) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Model 1320 spectrometer. X-ray powder patterns (CuKα radiation, 3°/min scan rate, 293 K) were acquired using a Philips PW100 diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (5 °C/min heating rate under normal atmosphere) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-LA500 FT instrument (500 MHz) in DMSO-d 6. Microanalyses for the compounds were carried out using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.).
elements.clean_text: Infrared (IR) spectra (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Model 1320 spectrometer. X-ray powder patterns (CuKα radiation, 3°/min scan rate, 293 K) were acquired using a Philips PW100 diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (5 °C/min heating rate under normal atmosphere) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-LA500 FT instrument (500 MHz) in DMSO-d 6. Microanalyses for the compounds were carried out using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.).

elements.content: The ligand pyebH was prepared by a modified literature method. The 4-methylpyridine (4-picoline) (4.9 mL, 50 mmol) was mixed with 4-formylbenzoic acid (7.6 g, 50 mmol) in acetic anhydride (40 mL) and the reaction mixture was heated at 145 °C for 8 h. It was then cooled to room temperature and the precipitated white-yellow crude product was collected by filtration and was washed several times with water followed by ethanol and finally with diethyl ether (8.1 g, yield 72%). 1H NMR for the ligand (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ(ppm): 8.54−7.31 (10H, aromatic protons and −CHCH−). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 121.1, 127.1, 128.4, 129.8, 130.4, 131.9, 140.4, 143.8, 150.1, 166.9. Anal. Calcd for C14H11NO2: C, 74.65; H, 4.92; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 73.83; H, 5.04; N, 6.03%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 226.0707 [M + 1]+.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of bis{4-[2-(4-Pyridyl)ethenyl] Benzoic Acid (PyebH)

The ligand pyebH was prepared by a modified literature method. The 4-methylpyridine (4-picoline) (4.9 mL, 50 mmol) was mixed with 4-formylbenzoic acid (7.6 g, 50 mmol) in acetic anhydride (40 mL) and the reaction mixture was heated at 145 °C for 8 h. It was then cooled to room temperature and the precipitated white-yellow crude product was collected by filtration and was washed several times with water followed by ethanol and finally with diethyl ether (8.1 g, yield 72%). 1H NMR for the ligand (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ(ppm): 8.54-7.31 (10H, aromatic protons and -CHCH-). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 121.1, 127.1, 128.4, 129.8, 130.4, 131.9, 140.4, 143.8, 150.1, 166.9. Anal. Calcd for C14H11NO2: C, 74.65; H, 4.92; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 73.83; H, 5.04; N, 6.03%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 226.0707 [M + 1]+.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and pyebH (0.5 mmol) was taken in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) and heated to 85 °C under autogenous pressure in a Teflon-lined steel bomb for 3 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C h−1) to room temperature. The colorless needle-shaped crystals formed were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: ∼44%. Anal. Calcd for C31H29N3O6Zn: C, 61.54; H, 4.83; N, 6.94%. Found: C, 61.82; H, 4.73; N, 7.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3434.5(mb), 2925.3(w), 1659.2(w), 1605.2(w), 1385(s).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)(H2O)} n  (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol) and pyebH (0.5 mmol) was taken in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) and heated to 85 °C under autogenous pressure in a Teflon-lined steel bomb for 3 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C h-1) to room temperature. The colorless needle-shaped crystals formed were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: ~44%. Anal. Calcd for C31H29N3O6Zn: C, 61.54; H, 4.83; N, 6.94%. Found: C, 61.82; H, 4.73; N, 7.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3434.5(mb), 2925.3(w), 1659.2(w), 1605.2(w), 1385(s).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ, 0.71073 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct methods using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program package. Only a few H atoms could be located in the difference Fourier maps in each structure. The rest were placed at calculated positions using idealized geometries (riding model) and assigned fixed isotropic displacement parameters. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ, 0.71073 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct methods using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program package. Only a few H atoms could be located in the difference Fourier maps in each structure. The rest were placed at calculated positions using idealized geometries (riding model) and assigned fixed isotropic displacement parameters. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table .

Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O and pyebH in a mixture of DMF and ethanol at 85 °C for 3 days as colorless needle-shaped crystals. It is formulated as {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)(H2O)} n by TGA, elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies while the phase purity of the bulk material is confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Once isolated, the complex is stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents as well as water. A broad peak at 3419 cm−1 and strong peaks at 1650 and 1403−1614 cm−1 in the IR spectrum of 1 are indicative of the presence of water, DMF, and coordinated carboxylates. Single crystal X-ray structural study reveals that the compound crystallizes in the C-centered monoclinic crystal system. The structure was successfully solved and converged in the space group Cc. The asymmetric unit consists of a Zn(II) ion, two pyeb1− ligands, one water molecule, and one DMF molecule. Each metal ion is coordinated to four different ligand units: two pyridine N from two pyeb1− units (Zn1−N1 = 2.047(5); Zn1−N2 = 2.079(5) Å) and three carboxylate O from another two pyeb1− units. One of the carboxylates is bonded in monodentate fashion (Zn1−O1 = 1.959(4) Å) while the other bonded in chelating mode (Zn1−O3 = 2.071(4); Zn1−O4 = 2.283 (4) Å). The N2O3 donor set forms a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (τ = 0.51) around Zn(II). Both Zn−O and Zn−N bond distances are comparable to those observed in other Zn(II) complexes. Furthermore, if the chelating carboxylate unit is treated as single connecting point, the Zn(II) center can be considered to have a pseudotetrahedral environment (Figure ) that is extended by linear pyeb1− units to give rise to a three-dimensional diamondoid framework. The ligand is not planar; rather the pyridyl group is slightly twisted with respect to the phenyl ring (dihedral angle, 13.01°). The diamondoid framework contains nanosized, distorted adamantanoid cages. The average separation of the adjacent Zn····Zn is 15.50 Å and a single cage is illustrated in Figure . The void in the framework is filled via mutual interpenetration of six more independent frameworks, generating a 7-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture (Figure ). Despite this 7-fold interpenetration, there is enough void space in the structure occupied by DMF and water molecules as guests. Interestingly, the mode of interpenetration is different from the normal mode and can be described as two sets of normal 4-fold and 3-fold nets (Figure ), that is, an unusual [4 + 3] mode of interpenetration. The independent equivalent cages are separated from each other by 8.409 Å (considering the Zn(II)····Zn(II) distance).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O and pyebH in a mixture of DMF and ethanol at 85 °C for 3 days as colorless needle-shaped crystals. It is formulated as {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)(H2O)} n  by TGA, elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies while the phase purity of the bulk material is confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Once isolated, the complex is stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents as well as water. A broad peak at 3419 cm-1 and strong peaks at 1650 and 1403-1614 cm-1 in the IR spectrum of 1 are indicative of the presence of water, DMF, and coordinated carboxylates. Single crystal X-ray structural study reveals that the compound crystallizes in the C-centered monoclinic crystal system. The structure was successfully solved and converged in the space group Cc. The asymmetric unit consists of a Zn(II) ion, two pyeb1- ligands, one water molecule, and one DMF molecule. Each metal ion is coordinated to four different ligand units: two pyridine N from two pyeb1- units (Zn1-N1 = 2.047(5); Zn1-N2 = 2.079(5) Å) and three carboxylate O from another two pyeb1- units. One of the carboxylates is bonded in monodentate fashion (Zn1-O1 = 1.959(4) Å) while the other bonded in chelating mode (Zn1-O3 = 2.071(4); Zn1-O4 = 2.283 (4) Å). The N2O3 donor set forms a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (τ = 0.51) around Zn(II). Both Zn-O and Zn-N bond distances are comparable to those observed in other Zn(II) complexes. Furthermore, if the chelating carboxylate unit is treated as single connecting point, the Zn(II) center can be considered to have a pseudotetrahedral environment (Figure ) that is extended by linear pyeb1- units to give rise to a three-dimensional diamondoid framework. The ligand is not planar; rather the pyridyl group is slightly twisted with respect to the phenyl ring (dihedral angle, 13.01°). The diamondoid framework contains nanosized, distorted adamantanoid cages. The average separation of the adjacent Zn⋅⋅⋅⋅Zn is 15.50 Å and a single cage is illustrated in Figure . The void in the framework is filled via mutual interpenetration of six more independent frameworks, generating a 7-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture (Figure ). Despite this 7-fold interpenetration, there is enough void space in the structure occupied by DMF and water molecules as guests. Interestingly, the mode of interpenetration is different from the normal mode and can be described as two sets of normal 4-fold and 3-fold nets (Figure ), that is, an unusual [4 + 3] mode of interpenetration. The independent equivalent cages are separated from each other by 8.409 Å (considering the Zn(II)⋅⋅⋅⋅Zn(II) distance).

elements.content: The framework is stabilized by H····O interactions (2.436−2.718 Å) originating from the H−atom of methyl group of lattice DMF and O-atom of carboxylate group of the nearby pyeb1− unit (H····O = 2.436 Å). Furthermore, C−H····O contacts (2.254−2.718 Å) between neighboring aromatic C−H groups of pyeb1- units and the O−atom of the DMF are also present. On the other hand, the lattice water molecule (OW1) makes short contacts (H····OW1 = 2.544−2.688 Å) with aromatic C−H groups. The H-atoms of DMF also show C−H····π interactions (2.790−2.895 Å) with aromatic C−H groups (Figure ). The framework is further supported by the (OW1)H····O(DMF) short contact (2.604 Å) (Figure ) forming a H-bonded one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain of guest molecules running along the crystallographic c axis.

Furthermore, C-H⋅⋅⋅⋅O contacts (2.254-2.718 Å) between neighboring aromatic C-H groups of pyeb1- units and the O-atom of the DMF are also present. On the other hand, the lattice water molecule (OW1) makes short contacts (H⋅⋅⋅⋅OW1 = 2.544-2.688 Å) with aromatic C-H groups. The H-atoms of DMF also show C-H⋅⋅⋅⋅π interactions (2.790-2.895 Å) with aromatic C-H groups (Figure ). The framework is further supported by the (OW1)H⋅⋅⋅⋅O(DMF) short contact (2.604 Å) (Figure ) forming a H-bonded one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain of guest molecules running along the crystallographic c axis.

elements.content:
Compound 1 shows an interesting guest exchange properties keeping crystallinity intact when it is kept in solvents like acetone, acetonirile (MeCN), and dry DMF (Scheme ).

To investigate the SC-SC guest exchange, a crystal of 1 with suitable size (mother crystal) was selected and used throughout at room temperature. When the mother crystal is immersed in acetone for 12 h, all lattice guest molecules are replaced by acetone to form the daughter crystal, {[Zn(pyeb)2](acetone)} n (2). The lattice parameters change slightly (Table ) in 2. The diamondoid framework is also maintained while one DMF and one water molecules in the lattice of 1 are replaced by a single acetone molecule. Compared to 1, the bond distances and bond angles pertaining to the framework remain constant within statistical errors. The acetone molecule is located in the channel in close contact with the pyeb1− ligand units [C····H = 2.79−2.83 Å, C····C = 3.34 Å) (Figure ). In the IR spectrum of 2 the presence of CO stretching frequency at 1703 cm−1 is observed. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 shows a total weight loss of 10% (calculated, 10.1%) in the temperature range, 45−130 °C corresponding to loss of the acetone molecules. Complete decomposition is achieved only after 400 °C. An analysis with PLATON suggests that the voids occupy 22.4% of the total unit cell volume. Similarly, when the daughter crystal (2) is placed in acetonitrile (MeCN), it transforms into a new daughter crystal, {[Zn(pyeb)2](MeCN)} n (3). Again, the crystal system and the space group remain unaltered in 3. The bond distances and bond angles also remain unaltered within statistical errors when compared with those in 1. Only change observed in 3 is the replacement of each acetone molecule by an acetonitrile molecule. Each MeCN molecule is H-bonded with the host framework (N····H = 2.71−2.72 Å, C−H····O (carboxylate) = 2.33 Å) (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Transformations

Compound 1 shows an interesting guest exchange properties keeping crystallinity intact when it is kept in solvents like acetone, acetonirile (MeCN), and dry DMF (Scheme ).

To investigate the SC-SC guest exchange, a crystal of 1 with suitable size (mother crystal) was selected and used throughout at room temperature. When the mother crystal is immersed in acetone for 12 h, all lattice guest molecules are replaced by acetone to form the daughter crystal, {[Zn(pyeb)2](acetone)} n  (2). The lattice parameters change slightly (Table ) in 2. The diamondoid framework is also maintained while one DMF and one water molecules in the lattice of 1 are replaced by a single acetone molecule. Compared to 1, the bond distances and bond angles pertaining to the framework remain constant within statistical errors. The acetone molecule is located in the channel in close contact with the pyeb1- ligand units [C⋅⋅⋅⋅H = 2.79-2.83 Å, C⋅⋅⋅⋅C = 3.34 Å) (Figure ). In the IR spectrum of 2 the presence of CO stretching frequency at 1703 cm-1 is observed. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 shows a total weight loss of 10% (calculated, 10.1%) in the temperature range, 45-130 °C corresponding to loss of the acetone molecules. Complete decomposition is achieved only after 400 °C. An analysis with PLATON suggests that the voids occupy 22.4% of the total unit cell volume. Similarly, when the daughter crystal (2) is placed in acetonitrile (MeCN), it transforms into a new daughter crystal, {[Zn(pyeb)2](MeCN)} n  (3). Again, the crystal system and the space group remain unaltered in 3. The bond distances and bond angles also remain unaltered within statistical errors when compared with those in 1. Only change observed in 3 is the replacement of each acetone molecule by an acetonitrile molecule. Each MeCN molecule is H-bonded with the host framework (N⋅⋅⋅⋅H = 2.71-2.72 Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅⋅O (carboxylate) = 2.33 Å) (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound 3 exhibits a strong peak at 2216 cm−1 in its IR spectrum that corresponds to CN stretching vibration. Thermal analysis of 3 shows weight loss of 7.1% (calculated, 7.3%) in the temperature range, 50−190 °C that agrees with the loss of MeCN molecules. The solvent accessible void in 3 is calculated to be 22% by PLATON. When the daughter crystal 3 is kept in dry DMF, a new daughter product, {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)} n (4) is formed. Structural investigation shows the crystal system and the space group to be same as that of the mother crystal (1) with only minor changes in the lattice parameters. Compared to 3, the only change observed in 4 is the replacement of MeCN by DMF molecules. Also, several C−H···O, C−H···π and H-bonding interactions between DMF and the host framework are observed (Figure ).

elements.content: In the IR spectrum of 4, the peak at 2215 cm−1 (due to CN stretching) disappears and a new peak at 1650 cm−1 appears consistent with the replacement of MeCN by DMF. Also, no broad band at 3500−3000 cm−1 is observed in 4 indicating absence of water molecules. The solvent accessible void volume of 4 is calculated to be 23.1%. The TGA of 4 shows that a weight loss of 12.3% occurs at 200 °C corresponding to the loss of DMF molecules; complete decomposition occurs beyond 400 °C. Compound 4 can also be formed when a crystal of 2 is kept in dry DMF for 12 h. The daughter crystal 2 or 3 takes about 12 h in aq DMF to change to the original crystal 1. Thus, guest exchanges are completely reversible.

elements.content: It should be noted here that none of the daughter crystals can be formed by direct solvothermal synthesis. During the solvent exchange, transparency of the single-crystal is retained. The possibility of dissolution of 1 in the successive liquids followed by crystallization or renucleation at the surface and growth of the new phase is excluded by photographs of the mother crystal and its transformations (Figure ) that show no change in size, morphology, color, or transparency.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized a pyridyl- and carboxylate-based linear ligand that forms a new 7-fold interpenetrated diamondoid coordination polymer with Zn(II) ion under solvothermal conditions. The compound 1 shows reversible exchange of solvents such as acetone, MeCN, and DMF at ambient temperature in SC-SC fashion.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have synthesized a pyridyl- and carboxylate-based linear ligand that forms a new 7-fold interpenetrated diamondoid coordination polymer with Zn(II) ion under solvothermal conditions. The compound 1 shows reversible exchange of solvents such as acetone, MeCN, and DMF at ambient temperature in SC-SC fashion.

cln_elements.content:
The ligand pyebH was prepared by a modified literature method. The 4-methylpyridine (4-picoline) (4.9 mL, 50 mmol) was mixed with 4-formylbenzoic acid (7.6 g, 50 mmol) in acetic anhydride (40 mL) and the reaction mixture was heated at 145 °C for 8 h. It was then cooled to room temperature and the precipitated white-yellow crude product was collected by filtration and was washed several times with water followed by ethanol and finally with diethyl ether (8.1 g, yield 72%). 1H NMR for the ligand (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ(ppm): 8.54−7.31 (10H, aromatic protons and −CHCH−). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 121.1, 127.1, 128.4, 129.8, 130.4, 131.9, 140.4, 143.8, 150.1, 166.9. Anal. Calcd for C14H11NO2: C, 74.65; H, 4.92; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 73.83; H, 5.04; N, 6.03%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 226.0707 [M + 1]+.

Preparation of {[Zn(pyeb)<sub>2</sub>](DMF)(H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and pyebH (0.5 mmol) was taken in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) and heated to 85 °C under autogenous pressure in a Teflon-lined steel bomb for 3 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C h−1) to room temperature. The colorless needle-shaped crystals formed were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: ∼44%. Anal. Calcd for C31H29N3O6Zn: C, 61.54; H, 4.83; N, 6.94%. Found: C, 61.82; H, 4.73; N, 7.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3434.5(mb), 2925.3(w), 1659.2(w), 1605.2(w), 1385(s).

Synthesis of bis{4-[2-(4-Pyridyl)ethenyl] Benzoic Acid (PyebH)

The ligand pyebH was prepared by a modified literature method. The 4-methylpyridine (4-picoline) (4.9 mL, 50 mmol) was mixed with 4-formylbenzoic acid (7.6 g, 50 mmol) in acetic anhydride (40 mL) and the reaction mixture was heated at 145 °C for 8 h. It was then cooled to room temperature and the precipitated white-yellow crude product was collected by filtration and was washed several times with water followed by ethanol and finally with diethyl ether (8.1 g, yield 72%). 1H NMR for the ligand (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ(ppm): 8.54-7.31 (10H, aromatic protons and -CHCH-). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 121.1, 127.1, 128.4, 129.8, 130.4, 131.9, 140.4, 143.8, 150.1, 166.9. Anal. Calcd for C14H11NO2: C, 74.65; H, 4.92; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 73.83; H, 5.04; N, 6.03%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 226.0707 [M + 1]+.

Preparation of {[Zn(pyeb)2](DMF)(H2O)} n  (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol) and pyebH (0.5 mmol) was taken in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) and heated to 85 °C under autogenous pressure in a Teflon-lined steel bomb for 3 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C h-1) to room temperature. The colorless needle-shaped crystals formed were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: ~44%. Anal. Calcd for C31H29N3O6Zn: C, 61.54; H, 4.83; N, 6.94%. Found: C, 61.82; H, 4.73; N, 7.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3434.5(mb), 2925.3(w), 1659.2(w), 1605.2(w), 1385(s).
